newsitem.title: GREECE: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK FINANCIAL NEWS - OCT 23.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK FINANCIAL NEWS - OCT 23.

text.p: Leading stories in the Greek financial press:
KATHIMERINI

-- The government is examining the possibility of imposing a special 'convergence' tax on selected high income earners and those with significant real estate holdings. Government members seeking new ways of raising revenues have differing ideas on the 'social dimension' of the economic measure.

--Also open for the government is the question of whether to tax profits from the transfer of majority share holdings from one company to another. Reports state that listed companies will most probably be excluded from the measure.

--Social benefits to be means-tested in the interests of a juster distribution and rationalisation of public expenditures. --Bank employees conditionally agree to bank mergers, saying a clear long-term strategy should guarantee viability and jobs.
IMERISIA

--Blow to buyouts of companies not listed on Stock Exchange as government looks at imposing two new taxes: one on property - dubbed 'the solidarity tax' - and the other on unearned increments from the buyouts of companies.

--State-run National Bank plans to write-off 63 billion drachmas in bad debts in the bank's portfolio, as part of plans to widen the bank's activities in the international market. --TVX Gold greets government-brokered settlement of Kassandra mines stand-off. The agreement, the company said, will allow it to resume work.
KERDOS

-- Ruling party PASOK Central Committee and Parliamentary Group to approve economic measures: the delay in the taking of decisions on the economy is primarily due to the need to soothe internal party feathers over the government's expected decisions on public spending, tax breaks, incomes policy and privatisations.
--The taxation of financial products is a near certainty, according to reports.
--Tax exemptions cost the state over one trillion drachmas in revenues, according to study.
--Meridien hotel may change hands from the Vardinoyiannis family to Grecotel.
EXPRESS
--Finance Undersecretary George Dyrs says state titles will not be taxed and 300 tax exemptions to go. Finance ministry denies new taxes will be imposed.

--Today sees premiere of the interministerial body on coordinating tourism policy, revived by Development Minister Vasso Papandreou, to oversee the work of a number of ministers involved in tourism matters.
--Denationalisation of Bank of Attica to be focus of tomorrow's meeting .
NAFTEMBORIKI

--Prime Minister Costas Simitis and National Economy and Finance Minister Yannos Papandoniou discuss proposals on economic policy for 1997 at yesterday's meeting. Decisions, however, will be taken after November 20, following discussion with party and government bodies.
--Department stores decide to open on Saturday evenings for a trial period. Commercial associations oppose the move. --Maria Petrakis, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4
